_exec_summary.SummaryText:
Risk Management Plan
Executive Summary
Gavilon Fertilizer LLC
Nickerson, KS.

I.    The Facility Policy:

The Facility owner, management, and employees of Gavilon Ferilizer LLC are 
committed to the prevention of any accidental release of anhydrous ammonia.  Local 
responders are encouraged to visit the Facility to gain first hand knowledge of the site. 
Employees are required to hold monthly safety meetings. Additional training is conducted on various sections of the facility's Process Safety Management plan. The Facility has prepared an internal written emergency action plan which includes ammonia releases. If an accidental release should occur,the facility is prepared to work with local fire departments, and other authorities to mitigate any release, and to minimize the
impact of a release on the population and environment.

II.   Facility Information:

The primary activity of the Facility is to manufacture and distribute agricultural fertilizer for the farming industry. Ammonia is received, stored, and used in the 
production of liquid fertilizer solutions and is an important 
source of Nitrogen for local agricultural crops.
 
The maximum quantity that can be stored at the facility is 131,300 pounds.  The  
method of receiving ammonia is by truck transport containing 40,000 pounds.  
The process is considered a batch process and operates intermittently.  

III.  Accidental Release Prevention:
   
The Facility takes guidance from material published by the American National Standards           
Institute "Safety Requirements for the Storage and Handling of Anhydrous Ammonia" 
K61.1, and Compressed Gas Association CGA G-2 for design, construction, and 
maintenance of the process equipment.  The Facility also has a Process Safety Management Program that dovetails with the RMP.  It is Management's practice to minimize the amount of ammonia held or stored at the facility. The Facility continues to review and look for means to improve operation, implement Best Manageme

nt Practices, and increase safety.  The Facility is also regulated by State ammonia regulations. 

IV. The Five Year Accident History:
       
There have been no accidental releases of ammonia related to the operation of this facility 
in  the past five years.  There have been no deaths, injuries, or significant property 
damage at the Facility. To the best of our knowledge, no off-site deaths, injuries, 
evacuations, sheltering in place, property damage, or environmental damage has occurred 
due to the operation of this facility.







Bibliography / References:
Technical Inc. prepared for NIOSH, HAZOP of  "Anhydrous Ammonia Use in 
Agricultural" 1991.

Clements Associates, Inc., Fairfax, VA;  "Health Effects for Ammonia, prepared for The 
Fertilizer Institute.

U.S. Environmental Protection Agency  "Chemical Emergency Preparedness and 
Prevention Advisory A? Ammonia", September 1991 Oswer 91-008.2, Series 8; No.2.

Ecology and Environment, Inc.,  "Generic Hazard Assessment and Off-site 
Consequences Analysis Kern and Kings Counties"' prepared for California Fertilizer 
Assoc. October 1990

American National Standard Institute, Inc., "American National Standard Safety 
Requirements for the Storage and Handling of Anhydrous Ammonia"  (K-61.1) March 
1989
